Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH Hi Rob, There can often be very minute traces of PSA remaining after surgery. Many times this is attributable to small amounts of benign prostate tissue left behind. There is always a discussion about standard PSA tests and ultrasensitive tests. For example, Mayo Clinic prefers to NOT use the ultra sensitive because they say it causes too much UNNECESSARY anxiety. I would not be worried about this at all. There are always micro-fluxuations of PSA at the macro level -- things that mean nothing at all. But they are picked up by the ultrasensitive, which is when worries can be triggered even though it is harmless. Good luck! Chuck Thanks Chuck....I agree if I had a regular PSA and not hama would just say <0.1....would not even know....my doctor says anything under 0.5 are meaningless fluctuations...will get another in April...thanks
Posts.Title: Post prostatectomy HAMA PSA rise from 0.02 to 0.04 (still < 0.1 guide) worry? HELP!

Posts.Content: Please I need some reassurance.... Had a radical prostatectomy in April 2009....all has been well for over 5 yrs - now 6 1/2 I have had my second HAMA Treatment PSA blood test-asked for HAMA test since I am on propecia and that can reduce PSA score a little.... 18 months ago I had 0.02 well below the 0.1 guidance as normal for those with prostatectomy...thought it was fine but wondered why I had ANY PSA without a prostate. Now 18 months later my HAMA PSA went from 0.02 to 0.04 - still well below <0.10 Quest Diagnostics considers normal and my doctor says absolutely no worry under .05.....still I worry a LITTLE because of the rise and the propecia. I also have some aches in my bladder area (although the ache could be muscle aches or associated with bad sciatica that seems to get worse with full bladder if that makes sense).....have had before and my doctor said it was not a big deal - still have to get up at night to pee even without a prostate...seems to be a little more recently but I have gained some weight....Had a clean complete urinalysis though. Can those knowledgeable on this board give me a little guidance/thoughts. I know I am lucky and probably should not worry but just wanted to ask the great people on this board. Also going in for a full physical soon. I would GREATLY appreciate it - this board is a WONDERFUL RESOURCE. thanks Rob Cos
Posts.Title: Post prostatectomy HAMA PSA rise from 0.02 to 0.04 (still < 0.1 guide) worry? HELP!

Many times this is attributable to small amounts of benign prostate tissue left behind. There is always a discussion about standard PSA tests and ultrasensitive tests. For example, Mayo Clinic prefers to NOT use the ultra sensitive because they say it causes too much UNNECESSARY anxiety. I would not be worried about this at all. There are always micro-fluxuations of PSA at the macro level -- things that mean nothing at all. But they are picked up by the ultrasensitive, which is when worries can be triggered even though it is harmless. Good luck! Posts.Title: Post prostatectomy HAMA PSA rise from 0.02 to 0.04 (still < 0.1 guide) worry? HELP!

Posts.Content: [QUOTE=newporter;291692]Any time post op PSA became detectable (without the < sign before the number) is a concern, even after 6 1/2 years but the good news is yours goes up slowly. Based on two data point your PSA doubling time is 18 months. A number of studies indicated PSADT is a good predictor of cancer specific survival. Folks with PSADT > 12 months usually had a good chance of surviving prostate cancer recurrence. Here is a review paper on this subject: Your doubling time based on two data points is 18 months, good news. But you really need at least another PSA test to confirm the PSADT number. Meaning for folks with PSADT >6 months, SRT improved survival by 40% (HR=0.6). You should be concern but I won't lose any sleep over it at this time. The old saying: "preparing for the worst but hope for the best" applies here. __________ Thanks for the quick reply...my doctor tells me the doubling is virtually meaningless when talking about numbers under 0.05....The doubling you are talking about I believe are higher levels...As chuck said - the fluctuations under 0.1 seem to be common...its why Mayo and others recommend the regular PSA instead of the ultrasensitive HAMA....probably made a mistake asking for HAMA....thanks for the article but again - it appears that BCR is considered above 0.2 and I am at 0.04 - and it does say "However, false positives occurring because of trace amounts of PSA produced by residual benign prostatic tissue, along with uncertainty about whether ultra-low levels of PSA will be followed by continued PSA increases, have led practitioners to continue to rely on the AUA definition for determining when clinically-relevant biochemical recurrence has occurred after prostatectomy." From the article.... "To describe biochemical recurrence after RP, a panel of experts from the American Urological Association (AUA) evaluated 53 different definitions of BCR following RP observed in the literature, and recommended adoption of a single definition. This involved the presence of a PSA greater than 0.2 ng/mL measured 6–13 weeks after RP, followed by a confirmatory test showing a persistent PSA greater than 0.2 ng/mL.9 Ultra-sensitive PSA assays have recently improved detection levels down to 0.01 ng/mL, and may possibly lead to better treatment outcomes through earlier adoption of salvage radiation therapy following RP.10,11 However, false positives occurring because of trace amounts of PSA produced by residual benign prostatic tissue, along with uncertainty about whether ultra-low levels of PSA will be followed by continued PSA increases, have led practitioners to continue to rely on the AUA definition for determining when clinically-relevant biochemical recurrence has occurred after prostatectomy." Rob

Posts.Title: Post prostatectomy HAMA PSA rise from 0.02 to 0.04 (still < 0.1 guide) worry? HELP!

Posts.Content: Hello - so I am now 5 yrs post prostatectomy (Davinci) and had positive margin...Because I take propecia - used to take proscar for yrs so when I stopped didn't want to lose ALL my hair :+( - I thought maybe I should get the HAMA (more exact?) PSA test as well for the 5 yr test since perhaps propecia could mask a psa increase like the proscar did. So I went off the propecia for a month before my test - I got my total and free PSA back today (YEAH UNDETECTABLE) and should have HAMA next week....so my questions - 1) what should I be looking/hoping for in the HAMA test - what would be "GOOD" for me 2) Is there any chance the normal total PSA is undetectable (good) and HAMA could be "bad" 3) Can someone explain exactly the difference between the tests - I looked on the "stickies" and didn't see this. Thanks a million to the great people on this board.
Posts.Title: Help please PSA. HAMA

Posts.Content: Thanks - I am grateful believe me but I had a strange turn of insurance so when my urologist sent me the HAMA quest request - I had to go to a primary care doctor and he ordered the PSA total (which I was grateful for because I don't know the HAMA test and may not have access to the urologist until July) - so I had the HAMA test done to send to urologist and same time and will get results and just want a little help about what you should look for and what it is about.
Posts.Title: Help please PSA. HAMA

Posts.Content: Sounds like the sciatica symptoms I had - U should maybe get an MRI on you back discs - you may have a protruding disc pushing on your sciatica nerve - it can cause pain and numbness in your back, often in your hip, your calf all the way to big toe sometimes....Good luck. Sciatica can cause mild pain, numbness and even excruciating pain....I had 3 yrs of hell and treatment and then got minimally invasive discectomy that was a miracle.
Posts.Title: very nervous

Posts.Content: Here is the comment on the review of my prostate that was taken out by the DaVinci machine.... "The tumor which is peripherally located involves the mid and anterior portions of the right lobe and is focally transected at inked margin. The area of transsection appears to represent prostatic parnchyma" Comment....The area of right apex positive for the tumor appears to represent transsection of prostatic parenchyma as opposed to transsection of tumor extending beyon prostatic capsule... I talked to my doctor (this operation was six yrs ago) about this back in 2009 as it appeared to me that they may have not cut out all the prostate - that the transsection was at the top of the prostate but may have left some in - he went back and looked at the slides and other parts of the prostate at the pathologist and assured me they got it all and that the very tip may have been burned off I think.....Now six yrs later as I said after having normal PSA's when I got the ultrasensitive HAMA PSA my PSA went from <0.02 to .04....in 18 months (as I noted in a previous post should I worry - thanks for your responses) ... so now I asked for pathology report again and wonder if a piece was left in Any help - I did go back to him and we will monitor my ultra sensitive PSA every 3 months...I am in good spirits but do want to understand the above...Would appreciate all of your interpretations and thoughts as I contemplate radiation if my PSA goes to 0.1 - hoping my propecia on and or calibration of the HAMA was off - my free and total PSA is still < 0.1 Thanks this board is a GREAT ASSET Rob Gleason Score 7
Posts.Title: Can someone please explain what transection of Prostatic Parenchyma means....

Posts.Content: ThANKS SO MUCH FOR YOUR REPLY - GOING TO GET A 3 MONTH PSA UPDATE BUT AM TRYING NOT TO WORRY Originally Posted by Michael F Hi again Rob! I'm not qualified help you with your question about prostate parenchyma in your path report. I have an opinion that pathologists have created their own language of "Pathologese" in which statements are often vague and ambiguous! If it continues to gnaw on your psyche 6+ years post op, you might be able to have your path report reviewed by an expert like Dr Epstein at Hopkins. Not sure though how beneficial this might be. Regarding your recent PSA measurements, Response # 8 to your post last Sept still stands. http://www.cancerforums.net/threads/...677#post291677 0.02 followed by 0.04 does NOT indicate a rise! Did the same lab do both of these PSAs? Looking at your previous posts, it appears that you used Quest. (Which BTW, others have recently reported issues with Quest reporting incorrect results) Have your MD's office call Quest and ask them: "Specifically for the Post Prostatectomy PSA with HAMA test, What is the Standard Deviation for PSA values that are < 0.10 ng/ml? I can assure you that 0.02 and 0.04 are well within the Std Dev for this assay. If so, this means that statistically, clinically and scientifically your 2 results are the SAME! Also, 0.04 is clinically "Undetectable" which means it is "0". Keep in mind, BR is defined as 2 or 3 consecutive increases in PSA. However they must be in a clinically "detectable" range which is > 0.05 ng/ml. Meanwhile try & chill down and not worry about it. A lot easier said than done! Being > 6 years post RP, BR remains a possibility BUT the likelihood / probability decreases with each passing year. I don't like Ultrasensitive PSAs but think they advisable for those who are in higher risk categories based on surgical and pathological findings at RP. Good luck! Hope you don't have to ask this question again. MF
Posts.Title: Can someone please explain what transection of Prostatic Parenchyma means....

Posts.Content: Thanks for your response....I am guessing if there was cancerous tissue left behind my PSA would not have been undetectable for over 6 yrs....now that my Ultrasensitive had a rise form <0.2 to 0.4 I revisited but am not really looking back much...will have another PSA 3 months after last just to see and will ask for Quest results
